project.name: documentation
project.description: The Gentoo Documentation Project is the official Gentoo project devoted to the complete and concise documentation of the Gentoo Project.

p.b: What we do, and who we are

longdescription.p: The Gentoo Documentation Project (GDP) is the official project of the Gentoo project responsible for the creation and maintenance of all official Gentoo documentation. The GDP is not a closed team of any sorts, but instead an open community committed to critiquing, and possibly integrating, viable user documentation.

The Gentoo Documentation Project was formed to address the need of complete documentation for Gentoo. In doing so, the GDP team is committed to the creation and maintenance of clear, concise, and original documentation. We will protect our users and developers by the use of free and open licensing on all documentation. The GDP is committed to remaining a free and open project, and will abide by the Social Contract set forth by the Gentoo Project.

project.resource: Tips and Tricks for Documentation Development

body.p: The first and foremost task of the GDP is to fix bugs in documentation and make sure that the online documentation is available and at all times current (including translations). However, there are other tasks in which the GDP is involved. Most tasks are of temporary nature - you will find information on the progress made on these tasks in the status updates. Unfinished tasks will be mentioned next.

As Gentoo's next release will be made in January 2004 all installation-specific documentation must be in tip-top shape. It is therefore vital that most efforts go into improving the installation instructions in such a way that, when the Gentoo release is made, no errors exist.
The following roadmap has been given to help this QA process:

tr.ti: From this day forward, only critical bugfixes to the Gentoo Handbook are allowed. This should make it possible for the translation teams to have their translations of the Gentoo Handbook in sync with the English document.
All documentation related to Portage and Gentoo-specific items must be in perfect shape.
Off-line versions of the Gentoo Handbook should be finished/reviewed and sent to the release engineering project for inclusion on the LiveCDs.

body.p: The main objective of the GDP is to have the online documentation be in perfect shape. Lots of users want to have offsite documentation too and even today most of them are left in the cold. The GDP should work on printable documentation (preferrably PDF), but albeit creating PDFs of its documentation isn't difficult, the main issues are:

ul.li: The online available PDFs should be fully in sync with the online HTML documentation. This requirement translates into the fact that the webserver(s) should be able to generate the PDFs on-the-fly from the sources provided.

The online available PDFs should be professionally-looking. This doesn't rhyme well with on-the-fly creation and more importantly, we currently don't have the resources to create professionally-looking PDFs.

body.p: If you are interested in helping out in this issue, don't hesitate to contact us. At this time, we believe that FOP is the best way to go as it allows us to process the GuideXML into XML-FO, which can then be parsed to PDF. Other options are of course also welcomed.

A second frequently-requested feature regarding the printable documentation is to have a one-page, show all Handbook which allows for easy printing of the Handbook. If we cannot provide a PDF as previously mentioned this option will be introduced. However, at this point most efforts are going to the PDF creation.

Many projects host documentation that can be of use for the Gentoo users. To centralise the documentation development efforts, those documentation should be placed under control of the GDP project. A listing of these documents is available under the resources.

A status update is a small text covering what the GDP has done since the previous status update. It is written by the operational manager and contains a quick overview on how the GDP progresses. If you want to know what lives in the GDP, and what is in the process of developing, this is what you should read.
Status updates don't usually talk about fixed bugs and updated documentation, although that is the main task of the GDP.

The Gentoo Documentation Project makes intensive use of the gentoo-doc@gentoo.org mailing list. On this mailing list discussions about documentation, subprojects, translations and more pass by.

To subscribe to this mailing list, send an empty e-mail to gentoo-doc-subscribe@gentoo.org. Once subscribed you can post to it by sending an e-mail to gentoo-doc@gentoo.org. To unsubscribe from the list, send an empty e-mail to gentoo-doc-unsubscribe@gentoo.org. There is also an online archive on news.gmane.org.

To participate in the Gentoo Documentation Project first join the mailing list at gentoo-doc@gentoo.org. Then ask if there are plans to support something that you are interested in, propose a new subproject that you are interested in, or choose one of the planned subprojects to work on. You may talk to the developers and users in the IRC channel #gentoo-doc on irc.freenode.net for more information or just to chat about the project or any subprojects. If you don't have the ability to actively help by contributing work we will always need editors to maintain the quality and accuracy of the overall product. All development, editing, and productive comments and feedback will be greatly appreciated.
